overview: - Review scalar vs. vector quantities and 1D sign conventions.
- Add vectors graphically using the head-to-tail method and interpret the resultant.
- Add perpendicular vectors using the Pythagorean theorem and inverse trig.
- Add non-perpendicular vectors with the component method (resolve → sum → recombine).
- Practice with two interactives: Graphical Vector Adder and Component Vector Adder.

steps: I. Fundamentals of Vectors
- A scalar has magnitude only. Examples: 10 m/s (speed), 5 kg (mass).
- A vector has magnitude and direction. Examples: 10 m/s North (velocity), 20 N Down (force).
//image _ vector_arrow_labeled.png
- We draw vectors as arrows: length ∝ magnitude; arrow direction shows the vector’s direction.
- One-dimensional vectors (on a line) add/subtract arithmetically; a negative sign indicates opposite direction.
- Example: +7 and −3 sum to +4.
II. Graphical Addition: Head-to-Tail Method
- Primary visual method for adding 2D vectors.
Step 1: Draw the first vector to scale and direction.
Step 2: Place the tail of the second vector at the head of the first.
//image _ head_to_tail_setup.png
Step 3: The resultant is drawn from the original tail to the final head.
//image _ head_to_tail_resultant.png
- Order does not matter (commutative: A + B = B + A).
//image _ commutative_property.png
- For >2 vectors, continue head-to-tail; resultant goes from the very start to the very end.
III. Mathematical Addition for Perpendicular Vectors
- Perpendicular vectors form a right triangle with the resultant.
A. Magnitude (Hypotenuse)
//image _ pythagorean.png
- Use the Pythagorean theorem: R² = A² + B².
- Example: 90 m East and 50 m North → R = √(90² + 50²) = √10600 ≈ 103 m.
B. Direction (Angle)
- Use inverse trig (often tangent).
- θ = tan⁻¹(opposite/adjacent). For the example, θ ≈ tan⁻¹(50/90) ≈ 29.1°.
- State direction fully: 29.1° North of East.
IV. Component Method for Non-Perpendicular Vectors
- Most general method; works for any angles.
//image _ vector_components.png
Step 1: Resolve each vector into x and y components.
- Vₓ = V × cos(θ),   Vᵧ = V × sin(θ).
- Set signs by quadrant (West = −x, South = −y).
Step 2: Sum components
- Rₓ = ΣVₓ,   Rᵧ = ΣVᵧ.
Step 3: Recombine
- Resultant magnitude: R = √(Rₓ² + Rᵧ²).
- Resultant angle: θ = tan⁻¹(Rᵧ / Rₓ), with quadrant-aware direction wording.
Ex 1 — Boat across a river: 16 m/s East + 9.0 m/s North → Resultant velocity
Step 1: Recognize perpendicular components (E and N).
Step 3: Direction θ = tan⁻¹(9.0/16) ≈ 29.4°.
Conclusion: 18.4 m/s at 29.4° North of East.
Ex 2 — Hiker: 11 km North then 11 km East → Displacement
Step 1: Perpendicular legs (11 N, 11 E).
Step 2: Magnitude R = √(11² + 11²) = √(242) ≈ 15.6 km.
Step 3: Direction θ = tan⁻¹(11/11) = 45°.
Conclusion: 15.6 km at 45° North of East.
Ex 3 — Two forces: 185 N East and 165 N at 30° North of East → Resultant force
Step 2: Sum components → Rₓ = 185 + 142.8 = 327.8 N;  Rᵧ = 82.5 N.
Step 3: Magnitude R = √(327.8² + 82.5²) ≈ 338 N.
Step 4: Direction θ = tan⁻¹(82.5/327.8) ≈ 14.1°.
Conclusion: ≈338 N at 14.1° North of East.
Ex 4 — Plane: 90 km/h North and 50 km/h West → Resultant velocity
Step 1: Treat North (+y) and West (−x) as perpendicular.
Step 3: Angle relative to North or East with correct quadrant.
Conclusion: ≈103 km/h at 29.1° West of North.
Practice 1 — Prompt: A hiker walks 11 km N then 11 km E. What total distance did they walk?
Practice 1 — Target: Distance is scalar → 11 + 11 = 22 km.
Practice 2 — Prompt: A plane flies East at 33 m/s with a 12 m/s wind blowing North. Find resultant speed and direction.
Practice 2 — Target: R = √(33² + 12²) ≈ 35.1 m/s; θ = tan⁻¹(12/33) ≈ 20° North of East.
Practice 3 — Prompt: Add a 4.0 km East vector to a 3.0 km North vector.
Practice 3 — Target: 3–4–5 triangle → 5.0 km at θ = tan⁻¹(3/4) ≈ 36.9° North of East.
Practice 4 — Prompt: Add the 1D vectors +7.5 m/s and −2.0 m/s.
Practice 4 — Target: 7.5 + (−2.0) = 5.5 m/s.
